My doctor and I are now working closely together to taper me off of clonazepam. I have replaced the clonazepam with Librium which is a long lasting benzodiazepine for the slow taper from clonazepam. The taper will take 3 months and then I will have to taper off of the Librium which is much less addictive than the clonazepam. My reason for this comment is in no way to inform anyone about their form of treatment for their condition. Rather
column5: it is to warn anyone of just how addictive clonazepam is and how difficult it is to get off of. Good luck to all and may God bless you!

I have been on clonazepam for 20 years. The drug helped me for years but ended up making me very suicidal. My physician and I are working closely together now on a very slow taper to get off of clonazepam. The taper requires a replacement drug to get off of it. I am in my third week of the taper replacing the clonazepam with Librium which is another benzodiazepine which is much easier to get off from than clonazepam. This taper will take 3 months. Then I have to be slowly tapered off of the Librium. When I was introduced to clonazepam
column4: I was never told just how addictive it is. While I would never try to interfere with anyone's treatment
column5: I would DEFINATELY caution anyone given clonazepam to be extremely careful because it is extremely addictive and extremely difficult to get off of. column1: 47$Condition: Panic Disorder$2/18/2016 2:56:30 AM$Reviewer: 55-64 on Treatment for 5 to less than 10 years (Patient) $5$5$5$In 2010 I was prescribed Clonazepam at 1 mg three times a day for severe anxiety/panic attacks. My wife was terminal with cancer since 2005 and was given 3 to 6 months to live after the initial surgery. She had 3 more surgeries and 5 rounds of chemo treatments and after each event I was told 3 to six months. She lived until 2011. I was already being treated for clinical depression (since 1995) and was in terrible shape. My doctor prescribed the Clonazepam and referred me to other options to deal with the anxiety. It really helped when the 'other' non-medical options failed to keep my mind in check. This med actually kept me from killing myself. Unfortunately my condition did not improve with the death of my wife and under close supervision of my doctor I remained on the Clonazepam until January of 2016 when the VA
column2: whom I have been under their care since 2013 when I moved back to my home town
column3: mandated that anyone using Clonazepam and any opiate had to choose to either stay with the Clonazepam or the opiate (I have been on morphine for degenerative discs). You could not use both because of the possibility of developing breathing problems. I had been taking both since 2010 and have not had any problems. The VA prescribed Hydroxyzine Pamoate at 25 mg twice a day. It has not helped my panic issues at all. It just makes me very sleepy and is giving me sinus headaches behind my eyes. I've been on this shit for two weeks and cannot function at all. I'm to damn drowsy and so damn agitated that I haven't left my apartment in a week. I looked up that med on WebMD and found out that the main function of it was for sinus issues
column4: not panic attacks. Note: I can't take antihistamines because of 'another' medical problem I have. I am at my wits end and need to get this resolved before I end up taking that dirt nap.

column2: 45-54 Female  on Treatment for 10 years or more (Patient) $5$5$5$"I have been taking 2.5 mg of Clonazpam for 20+ years.  It is an extremely effective medication for panic disorder
column3: general anxiety
column4: and OCD for me.  I am 52 years old and after making planes turn around in the sky and 4 hours in security (pre 9-11) as I was certain my plane would crash
column5: I was prescribed it starting at one mg a day.  After having a panic attack in traffic on the Golden Gate Bridge and getting out of my car to practice my breathing techniques at the rail of the Bridge
column6: with people screaming ""don't jump
column7: it was increased to the level I now take. (Fortunately it was late 1990's and a adorable Dr. In a Porche recognize what was happening and calmed the situation). So no arrest...  Lastly
column8: I want everyone to know
column9: one must tritrat off only with your physicians care and very slowly.  The withdraw symptoms are horrific when I tried once.  Eyes bouncing around shakes sweats etc.  this is drug dependence not addiction.  I also do not believe it to be an acute medication but not sure.  Xanax etc. Give me a hang over feeling the next day or. Headaches mid day.  Drinking and taking this mediation will make a person forget - memory loss.  Just make sure you follow Dr. 's advice to the letter.  Oh yes
column10: and during the withdrawal if too fast
column11: one can actually have seizures- even if you were not prescribed it for any seizure disorder like Epilepsy.  Thank you for reading this."

45-54 Male  on Treatment for 5 to less than 10 years (Patient) $5$1$5$"Initially this drug seemed safe and useful. I started this drug for anxiety and stress. Unfortunately
column3: I had been extremely misled of its danger. The prescribing doctor eliminated it too quickly and then cowardly denied its correlation to seizures of my jaw radically chomping during the night
column4: severe insomnia
column5: panic attacks
column6: thought process disturbances
column7: and much more miserable consequences. When searching for what was wrong with me so desperately
column8: I went to over twenty doctors that denied such possibility could happen until one that diagnosed me with Post Acute Withdrawal Syndrome (PAWS). Now
column9: not one doctor can or has denied its correlation to my very ailing condition. I've never felt as though I was going to die so many times in my life
column10: and I almost have many times. Had I known about its brain damaging factors
column11: I would never had touched it. Stay away from this drug. Too many doctors are not managing it well and setting people up for misery on top of misery down the road. This will be the cause of your panics
column12: and much worse. My condition is possibly lifelong. It also made it to where I cannot feel pleasure whatsoever and more severe consequences. Thanks docs.

column1: Do your own research and do not trust the loosely prescribing doctors that try to convince you that it is safe for long-term use when it is not.
One well written NYU report link is http://epilepsy.med.nyu.edu/treatment/medications /clonazepam
The Ashton Manual is also a great reference book that most of the world uses except the US.
Do your research before you use this drug! I was stuck on this drug for years. Don't let it happen to you!
Avoid this drug if you can!"

column2: 45-54 Male  on Treatment for 5 to less than 10 years (Patient) $5$4$3$"As a long term sufferer of RSD or CRPS
column3: I have found that this drug has been very effective with helping me Cope with the many stressor's that this disease/syndrome presents to the ""silent sufferer's"". After an exhaustive and frustrating search for answers to
column4: ""what exactly do I have and why am I not getting any better?"" After being misdiagnosed and having so called ""Pain Management Specialists"" send me to Psychiatrist's who misdiagnosed me and started and kept me on medications that have terrible side affects such as constant dry mouth
column5: skin rashes
column6: swelling of the tongue (so bad I could not speak)and the list goes on. This PAIN was NOT IN MY HEAD as I was told point blank. RSD/CRPS causes your sympathetic nerves & central nervous system to report REAL NERVE DAMAGE & it reacts to this by causing a ""Hyper-Nerve Stimulation"" which the BRAIN CANNOT HANDLE! Victims of this incurable disease/disorder or syndrome know how this manifests itself physically and this ""Hyper-Nerve Stimulation"" also causes our BRAIN to over-react to common stress ""Hyper-Sensitively""! Forget it if you experience major stress like the loss of a child or parent spouse. That's  when we experience ""flare-ups""! If you are unlucky enough to have foreign surgical objects such as metal screws
column7: plates
column8: etc. inside of you then watch out when the barometer drops and the weather changes because the PAIN
column9: BURNING
column10: NUMBNESS
column11: JOINT & EXTREMITY SWELLING
column18: (PROBLEMS URINATING in my case) are part of the ""Internal Storm"" reacting to the ""External Storm or weather front getting ready to come through. PRAISE THE LORD BECAUSE FINALLY I FOUND A DOCTOR WHO TOOK ONE LOOK AT ME AND IN 15 MINUTES DIAGNOSED ME CORRECTLY AND PRESCRIBED THIS MEDICATION ALONG WITH AN INTRATHECAL PUMP TO DELIVER (YES STRONG NARCOTIC MEDICATION) DIRECTLY INTO MY SPINE THUS AVOIDING OR MINIMIZING THE FURTHER DAMAGE TO MY KIDNEYS

45-54 Male  on Treatment for 2 to less than 5 years (Patient) $5$5$5$"As ayoung child (approx
column4: I suffered from leg pains at night and also an unresistable urge to hit my head againt my pillow.

column1: Both my parents suffered from mood swings which i did not understand at the time. Eventually at about the age of 20
column2: my mood swings started to developed
column3: but ony lasted for a couple of days. I visited my doctors about my systoms
column4: but was never taken seriously. Most shrugged their shoulders and moved on. After my divorce and consequent remarriage
column5: my wife began to become concerrd about my mood swings and suggested that I see a therapist. I did this but it did not help.

column2: symptoms became more frequent and I recognize that I was becoming more like my father concerning his rapid mood swings.
I met a doctor who took interest in my concerns and actually spent over an hour with me listening itently to what I had to. After running serveral test an reviewing my medical records
column3: he suggested that I try the drug clonazepam @ 2mg 1x.  I don't know if this was co-incindental
column4: but the first night a took clonazaepam
column5: i had the best night sleep that i have had in 35 years. No leg pains
column6: no rumination and felt like a rejuvenating person again. I have been on this medication for about 4 years at the same dosage
column7: but the effectiveness seem to be lessening. Obviously
column8: different medications affect people differntly
column9: but if my experience can help anyone
column10: please consult your doctor about this drug. "

174$Condition: Panic Disorder$2/21/2013 1:47:33 AM$Reviewer: Martin E, 25-34 Male  on Treatment for 5 to less than 10 years (Patient) $4$4$5$After multiple hits to the head from sports and other activities,I developed lasting effects from multiple concussions.I waited a year before medication, with no improvement.Symptoms were sensitivity to light,sound,horrible constant vertigo,visual disturbances,and after all of that I developed an anxiety issue also.At this point, I didn't want to live anymore.I could barely function doing simple daily living tasks, my neuro put me on this med, and it has saved my life. It has helped with so many of the brain problems, and also takes the edge off the anxiety. Dose is .5 in a.m., .25 afternoon, and .5 at night. Cons of this med are withdrawals if I don't take it for a day, and it makes me kind of drowsy.But I can still get through the work day, take a nap afterward, and feel fine. Allows me to live my life, if I have to take a short nap each day in exchange for my life back, that's fine with me. And also, very important, DO NOT drink with it! I did this more than a couple times, and blacked out, not remembering anything, or just bits and pieces.

column3: however I found that I need to take this at night no later than 7 to 8 hours before I need to be up the following morning. It is really helping better than the muscle relaxer. I am a person who has been on pain meds for over 15 years due to a car accidenct where I was rear ended and have so many things wrong with my back that it is hard to find ways of dealing with the multiple types of pain due to multiple diagnoses. I advise everyone I speak with to not give up and keep fighting for your rights especially when you are dealing with doctors who seem to think they have the manual to your body and know your body better than you do. Keep fighting for what is right for you no matter what anyone else might think. I have been fighting for my own rights for many years and have finally found a team of doctors who seem to listen to what I have to say and seem to understand my frustration of many years of dealing with doctors who don't seem to want to understand and/or deal with my issues. I have even had to deal with doctors and SSI tell me that I am too young to be having all of these issues. Whose right is it to say that anyone is too young to have any type of medical issue regardless of the issue or what caused it or your age. KEEP FIGHTING FOR YOUR RIGHTS AND WHAT IS RIGHT FOR YOU PERSONALLY!!!!!!

column1: 286$Condition: Other$1/12/2012 6:13:00 PM$Reviewer: A word of warning
column2: 45-54 Female  on Treatment for 5 to less than 10 years (Patient) $3$1$5$I took clonazepam for 9 years to help with insomnia and anxiety. Although it worked well at first
column3: I needed higher and higher doses over time to achieve the same level of efficacy. This worried me and I decided to stop taking it. Even with a doctor's supervision and a very gradual dose reduction
column4: I still experienced horrible withdrawal symptoms. I would strongly advise against EVER taking this drug
column5: even for a short time. The road to dependence (both physical and mental) is a quick and slippery slope. An outstanding web site to look at is www.benzo.org.uk. You will find out about clonazepam's adverse effects
column6: what withdrawal symptoms can occur
column7: and learn about a time-tested method to get off of it. It's best however
column8: to never take it in the first place.

I am not overly tired and have had some weight issues, not certain which medication is the cause though.

299$Condition: Panic Disorder$12/10/2011 2:56:05 AM$Reviewer: Fortressofcomfort, 35-44 Male  on Treatment for 2 to less than 5 years (Patient) $4$4$3$Good but very sedating.  Better for treating insomnia than for in-day anxiety relief.  I prefer Valium during the day; it provides just as good anxiety relief but makes me less drowsy.  10mg Valium is equal to approx 1mg of clonazepam.  I find Valium and Klonipin to not be addictive but found Xanax to be very addictive.  All of thes bentos will build up in your system and can turn you into a zombie quickly, so stick to the prescribed dosage.  I think that is 4mg/day for Klonipin and 40mg/day for Valium.  Summary: if you find it doesn't relieve your anxiety, or is too sedating, ask your doc if you can try Valium.  There's a reason Klonipin is not indicated for anxiety!

column1: 401$Condition: Panic Disorder$12/24/2010 7:48:52 PM$Reviewer: marketwizard, 25-34 Male  on Treatment for 2 to less than 5 years (Patient) $5$5$5$Dosage 2mg q1 t.i.d. (6mg/day)

Cerefolin NAC (L-Methylfolate) 7.5mg/day This new generation of vitamin requires a script although not a drug. It's a manipulated form of folic acid 8 times what you get from the GNC version but ALL of it crosses the blood brain barrier whereas OTC versions don't cross at all! That's why ur pee stinks (sorry). It's expensive & insurance won't pay but anyone on SSRI/SNRI's should be on this. It triggers the brains ability to start producing Dopamine
column2: Seratonin and Norepinephrine! If there's nothing to ""reuptake"" then there's no point in using a re-uptake inhibitor (SSRI like Zoloft/Paxil etc...) Everyone should take this nutritional supplement if they take anti-depressants like Effexor
column3: Paxil
column4: Zoloft
column5: Remeron
column6: Cymbalta
column7: Prozac
column8: etc... The company making this curiously makes an almost identical substitute called ""Deplin"" which one thinks competes with the other
column9: but they're both made by Pamlabs. Go to pamlab.com & can get your discount card cuz it's very pricey. It's a miracle vitamin for me. I had a brain injury because of a fall and lost short term memory retention. Dr's said it would take years for it to return. I started taking Cerefolin NAC w/ my Zoloft/Wellbutrin cocktail and it worked immediately. Both Deplin and Cerefolin work the same cuz the main ingredient is L-Methylfolate. Deplin is marketed as something that helps your anti-depressants while Cerefolin is marketed as early stage memory loss or Alzheimer's but it also contains B-12 and another Vitamin which actually makes the Cerefolin NAC a much more effective choice than Deplin for those taking anti-depressants while in either case
column10: I don't see any value in Deplin cuz u'll need Vitamin B supplements as well. Go figure."

column2: 25-34 Male  on Treatment for 2 to less than 5 years (Patient) $5$5$5$"Have been taking this med for almost 4 years. With originally Effexor and then I was weened off of that. For about 1.5 years (starting 2 years ago) I only used 0.5MG's maybe a half dozen times total. At that point they were no good and it was me dealing with my panic and anxiety attacks. Obout 6 months ago I went back on them because of losing myjob and issues with getting unemployment payments. Was put on Cymbalta for nervous ticks and this has been only used maybe another half dozen times. when i need it it works great. I never got addicted or needed to watch out that I was going to be dependent on it. I can see a life with very few panic attacks on the horizon soon. I can also say that Xanax only worked for a while for me and then didn't.

column1: It is also extremely important for people to make sure that they dont up the doses without help from a doctor first. Also if someone is a drinker this med or any anti anxiety med will have less if any effects.

I feel that this med has helped me so much with another med to control the main anxiety issue plus a little Cognitive behavioral therapy has helped me. I have also by attacking my attacks not relying on this med to cure me. Its all up to me.

412$Condition: Seizures with Irregular Muscle Contractions$12/3/2010 1:41:07 PM$Reviewer: Doctor's Friend, 55-64 Male  on Treatment for 5 to less than 10 years (Patient) $5$5$5$I have advanced osteoarthritis and several bulging discs which are inoperable.  I did have a laminectomy at L4/5 thirty years ago.  I was experiencing random muscle spasms in my back, right leg and right arm so severe that I was medically retired (total disability) under Social Security. I am now 63 and have been retired about five years.  My last Orthopedic doctor agreed to try and lessen the spasms with an anti anxiety drug, I had learned from a Pharmacist acquaintance that it might be of use.  The relief was verging on spectacular  and a year later when I had moved to another State and entered a Pain Relief Clinic the medication was changed to Clonazepam 2mg twice daily, as needed.  My condition improved so much that 2 mg at bedtime has all but stopped the spasms,  On occasion I may have to use more but I have had no side effects and my quality of life is up 50%.

column2: 35-44 Female  on Treatment for 5 to less than 10 years (Patient) $5$1$5$i started taking these after my first divorce..i took them for 5 years..was not advised that they were highly addictive..had to go without for 3 days because didnt have money to refill..thought i was having a panic attack and actually was going through withdrawals..i started have heart palpatations and severe chest pain..started hallucinating..thought someone was trying to kill me..wanted to jump out a window or walk out in front of a car..anything to stop it..all i could do was push my speed dial not knowing who i was calling and luckily it was my best friend which was 45 min away and i could not even talk..she knew something was wrong and she stayed on the phone and called 911 on her way to my house because she knew she couldnt make it to me in time..they came and i was trying to have a stroke & heart attack at the same time..could not feel my body..had no clue where i was or what i was doing..they said if she had waited to call them til she got to me i would have died from a massive heart attack..i was only 30 when that happened..had to go to hospital and finish going thru detox..to this day
column3: which has been 2 years since that situation
column4: i crave the klonipin..i cant even have them in the house..i have never been addicted or abused any medication..i was terrified and have advised everyone i know to not take them..after i got to the hospital and came out of it
column5: the dr told me that if i ever took one again i would automatically get addictetd again..its a scary felling when u feel like u cant do without a medicine..since then i am great..no adverse side effects of not taking it now..but i did hypnosis & have not had a panic attack in a year & a half..on the internet my boyfriend found a website..instant-hypnosis.com..find the cd for panic attacks..order it..its worth every penny..LORI

19-24 Male  on Treatment for 1 to 6 months (Patient) $5$5$4$"It was hard getting my doctor to prescribe a benzo

column4: a very low dose that belies how effective it's been for me.

column1: In social situations I no longer feel like I'm always doing or saying embarrassing or stupid things; my speech and behaviors are no longer inhibited by a perceived omnipresent public scrutiny. When I drink now
column2: it's not a desperate move to ""prep"" myself for a meeting or party. Instead it's for my own enjoyment.

column1: In class I engage the professors regularly (often zealously with my opinions) and have become good friends with some of them. I do find it difficult at first to stay awake when it kicks in during a class
column2: but I had that problem before the clonazepam. Perhaps the only negative aspect is the memory loss
column3: an effect I perceive probably more than most people
column4: being a student. The gaps in information
column5: when they exist
column6: are generally negligible anyway.

column1: I've been on 200mg Zoloft for years now (for the aforementioned anxieties and OCD)
column2: and yet I always felt that my symptoms weren't completely resolved. Though I am aware of the fleeting nature of benzodiazepines' anxiolytic effects
column3: I have come to terms with the possibility of being on such a drug for a long time. Unless it leads to abuse
column4: the benefits far outweigh the costs of klonipin. I am a better person now
column5: because I don't have to live in fear."

column2: 35-44 Female  on Treatment for less than 1 month (Patient) $1$1$5$"I was given b/c my neurologist thought I was having break-through simple seizure activity (although I thought I had an anxiety attack or two).  Originally was perscribed 1mg 3x a day.  I only took 1 a day at first and seemed to get a little better after 4-5 days.  Then it was the weekend and I slept through most of that holiday weekend. I thought I should take 2 since I was perscribed 3 a day and after 2 days of that I was groggy all day at work and even fell asleep at work briefly.  After about 9-10 days of taking
column3: I became a disoriented
column4: walking zombie.

column1: After leaving a work party (w/literally 2 sips of wine) at approx. 7:30
column2: I fell asleep on the train ride home (which happened often while taking the medicine but never before in many years of riding the train).  The conductor woke me up and I knew I was a little tired but never thought I was too bad to drive.  I was leaving a (thankfully) nearly empty train station parking lot and blacked out or fell asleep and crashed my car into a cement light fixture.  It knocked me awake and I thought someone hit me and looked around and there was no one in sight.  That was a Thursday
column3: that weekend I tried 3 (as perscribed) and slept most of the weekend and was groggy for a couple days after discontinuing med altogether.  I stopped the med and called the dr but she was on vacation.  A couple weeks later she had me try much lower dose (.125 mg 2 - 3 x day) but it still made me tired but not as bad and didn't seem to notice any real positives."

column2: 45-54 Male  on Treatment for less than 1 month (Patient) $3$2$4$"Clonazepam worked very well the first week. I could sleep for 6 hrs and not wake up in a state of panic with a racing heartbeat.  My anxiety symptoms were calmer too.  But after a week I started feeling general anxiety about situations where I normally have just a little uneasiness.   As the 2nd week went on.. my anxiety grew stronger and stronger.. but when I hit a state of panic attack the drug kicks in and I feel calmer and don't feel the emotional effects of the panic attack.  I do have the racing heartbeat though.. so I take a beta blocker (propanolol) to help slow it down a bit. I was still able to sleep. Until two nights ago when my anxiety about being able to get to my doctors appointment on time woke me up too early.   then I spoke with the doctor about my symptoms and he said I was having daily anxiety withdrawal as the drug started to wear off the next morning.  He switched me to tazepam but the pharmacy wants 430 dollars for 60 pills... who can afford that? The doctor also put me on Citalopram 10 mg yesterday for 6 days and then go to 20 mgs after that.  I took my first pill last night and woke up early so I have insomnia and feel very tired and am subject to anxiety still.  I would like to get off clonazepam soon so I can get some sleep and not feel so exhausted and vulnerable.

column1: For short term use.. 2 to 3 weeks
column2: this drug is okay. For long term use.. I suggest you use something else."

column1: 786$Condition: Panic Disorder$3/19/2009 10:57:56 PM$Reviewer: 55-64 Male  on Treatment for 10 years or more (Patient) $5$5$5$It is hard to explain. One day at work I FELT LIKE I WAS HAVING A STOKE. I was 35 years old.I HAD CHILLS
column2: RIGHT SIDE WAS NUMB. I ASKED MY BOSS TO CALL AN AMBULANCE SHE WOULD NOT SO I DROVE MYSELF TO HOSPITAL. As I was walking to my CAR MY FEET FELT RUBBERY BUT I MADE IT TO MY CAR. AT HOSPITAL THEY DID AN MRI THE NEXT DAY ALL WAS FINE.As time went on I would have this feeling in the lower chest where the rib cage comes together. I JUST COULD NOT FUNCTION. I would have to go and lay down and a few hours later I would be ok. I took many trips to er with same results. They could find nothing wrong.I had all the tests MRI
column3: CAT SCAN
column4: BLOOD WORK
column5: CERTAIN URINE TESTS
column6: EKG
column7: EEG
column8: STREss TEST ALL WAS GOOD. SO i TRIED ANOTHER DOCTOR SAME RESULTS. Finally a doctor sent me to a psychiatrist. He put me on .5 mg klonopin one at bedtime. That was it I was cured. But I worry about dependency. So I stopped taking it after a month and the feeling in chest came back
column9: my legs would feel weird and I just felt like I was going to pass out. I am happy go lucky I do not understand. But another psychiatrist said it is how my body handles stress even though you do not realize you are stressed. so he put me on clonazepam .5 mg one a day but i only take as needed. I have been taking for 10 years but the key is take as needed. I take half .5 mg pill as needed. I use about 60 pills a year taking a half pill when needed.That would be .25 mg. Which would be 120 doses a year.The doctor says take one pill a day but I will not afraid of dependency so i take as needed maybe 3x  aweek  it varies. I have not had a trip to ER since. I still feel stressed at times but the pill seems to do the trick. If i took one .25 every day maybe I would be fine all the time but I believe I would have to up the doseage as time went by and eventually it would no longer work. The doctor said he cannot see how .25 when needed works but if it does ok. Believe me it works.

column6: Oxycodone and Morphine this was around 2006. I gave it up for about one week and I could not stand up

column1: So regardless of need or not I could not quit Clonazepam. Now all the side effects in the book are working on me but I can’t quit. I strongly oppose giving this type of medication to a patient with sleep disorder. Yes my life is like hell can’t do with it or without just read the severe side effects and imagine being living with them by the way all my back pain came back 2 months after the last surgery.To all my co-patients don't take this unless you have the problems it is primarily made for.

column3: but its short life left me feeling 10 times worse when it wore off 3-4 hours later.  This is when I started Clonazepam(Klonopin) and was started at 1mg 4/day.  My body built up a tolerance and I got to the point where I was taking up to 20mg/day just to stay leveled.  I tried going off of it and went through hell and now I just take whatever whenever just to avoid the withdrawal hell. column10: but I know once I became dependent on it I was done. I hate Benzos!!!

967$Condition: Panic Disorder$6/3/2008 7:57:19 PM$Reviewer: eravenheart, 35-44 Male  on Treatment for 1 to 6 months (Patient) $3$3$2$I started on Lorazepam but an ER doc decided that it was not working enough because it didn't last long enough.  I ended up on 2mg of Clonazepam a day.  I took that for about 2 weeks after almost 3 months on Lorazepam.  A new pcp decided to cut my dosage down to .25mg a day all at once.  The withdrawal started immediately.  It has not been too bad yet but I'm only in my 5th day.  On the second day I just stopped taking it altogether since it was doing nothing for me anyway (the withdrawal symptoms create their own anxiety).  However
column2: while on this drug
column3: I did not have a single panic attack.  I did experience moderate to severe dizziness at times (especially on standing rapidly or moving my head too quickly) and a severe loss of appetite.  I thought that bad at first but discovered that eating very small portions more often allowed me to gain my appetite back.  Since I was overweight to begin with
column4: this turned out to be good as I have lost nearly 20 pounds.  I have read from others that they take doses only when they feel a full panic attack coming on rather than routinely to combat constant anxiety.  I will be attempting that if I actually have a full blown panic attack.  I'm close a lot of the time right now but know that much of it is withdrawal.  I would recommend that
column5: if you have been prescribed this medication for routine
column6: daily dosage that you talk with your doctor about changing to an ""as needed"" drug to avoid serious withdrawal symptoms.  Also
column7: avoid alcohol when you've taken this.  It really knocks me for a loop.  All in all
column8: it is a decent drug but the addiction factor really needs to be considered before taking.  Good luck to you and all of us dealing with this medication."

column1: 983$Condition: Panic Disorder$4/23/2008 12:58:46 AM$Reviewer: 45-54 Female  on Treatment for 5 to less than 10 years (Patient) $5$4$5$I have been taking this Rx for nearly 8 yrs after taking Ativan for several yrs for panic attacks. It has been very effective in reducing/preventing panic attacks & reducing stress reactions to social situations - tho recovery groups (CoDA and Al Anon) have provided the most help in that respect.  IS habit forming - previously on Valium many yrs ago (benzo also) - MUST reduce gradually as I went off cold & results are shakiness and nervousness.  Did not make me sleepy as I take other Rx for migraine/muscle spasm that are sedating and my body has gotten used to fighting off the sleepiness.  I am pleased to finally be OFF of this med as I am also on Wellbutrin and Prozac and hope to get off them someday too.

column2: 19-24 Female  on Treatment for 5 to less than 10 years (Patient) $5$5$5$"I take Klonopin (1.5 mg) and Lexapro (20 mg) to treat anxiety and ADD-HI (hyperactivity/impulsivity).  I've been on both of them for about five years and have never had more control over my life.  I take them at night to make sure that I can sleep because I'm usally ""wired"" from the effects of my ADD-HI.  The Klonopin itself is a life saver because it calms me down enough that I can get a decent night's sleep.  The only thing unfortunate about it is that I am sometimes drowsy if I don't get at least 8 hours of sleep (as with any sleeping pill).  I don't take it if I've been drinking or have taken Benadryl for my allergies so I have never had withdrawal sympotoms or adverse side effects.  I tend to take a ""vacation"" from the Klonopin some weekends as to prevent a negative interaction with alcohol.  This drug is very effective if you use it properly."

45-54 Female  on Treatment for less than 1 month (Patient) $4$4$4$I've was prescribed Clonazepam by my Primary Physician; my depression had advanced to a somewaht mild form of Bipolarism.  Given the the dosage prescribed (.5mg)
column3: I didn't think it was going to work
column4: given that I was taking 40 mg of Prozac.  Upon taking the first pill I noticed a different within an hour; I slept liek a baby for the first time in years.  When I work up
column5: I felt such a sense of calm that it pleased me--yet frighted me-at the same time.  I went to work for the FIRST TIME with a PLEASANT DISOPSITON; I didn't need to get two martinis at lunchtime in order to get through the rest of the day.  I wasn't SNAPPING OFF at my family that evening. Granted
column6: by the FOURTH TABLET I began feeling quite lightheaded
column7: walking somewhat wobbly.  I ate a good breakfast and some fruit and relaxed.  Of all the meds I have taken over the past eleven years
column8: I have found this one to be working (so far so good). As for the possibility of becoming addicted to the meds
column9: I been through enough enough addictions to such meds that I force my self to rise above it--because I want to get better.  I don't feel I'm in the place to recommend this to anyone; what can be one person's Nirvana can be another person's Purgatory. If you have a good doctor (Primary
column10: Psycologist
column11: other) whom you feel you can trust and will prescribe a med that will work for you (and only YOU)
column12: go for it.  But always remember and don't ever forget--the meds are'nt going to solve whatever problems triggering your symptoms--YOU ARE.

column2: 55-64 Female  on Treatment for 1 to less than 2 years (Patient) $1$1$1$  This is one of the most dangerous drugs in the world and I can't understand how any doctor in good conscience could ever prescribe it for anyone.  I am so sorry I ever took that first pill...I began having problems from the start but didn't think it was the drug and the doctor didn't seem to know what I was experiencing was coming from the drug either.  I would get extremely lightheaded
column3: so much so I could barely function; all I wanted to do was lay around because I had no energy or interest in doing anything
column4: even the most simple things became difficult to do. It also numbs you emotionally and my mind and memory have been dulled.  Take anything but this drug.  No one explained to me that this drug is a class that is not like antidepressants
column5: but it's a hynotic drug.  It should be used ONLY for very severe cases of panic or seizures...not for anxiety like I have and even then for only short periods of time...two-4 weeks. Please don't let anyone talk you into taking this drug.  You willl find it's a living hell if you ever want to come off of it.  From the things I have read
column6: everyone who has tried to come off of it has had horrible experiences with withdrawal due to your whole nervous system being dependent upon it.  Your body is no longer able to function normally.  Your brain no longer manufactures its own hormones because this drug has taken over.  It will take a long time for your brain to begin to make it's own again.  Other organs are affected
column7: also.  I would like to convince the whole world of the dangers of this drug and tell them that any doctor who puts you on it
column8: find another doctor.

column2: 45-54 Male  on Treatment for 1 to 6 months (Patient) $4$4$4$I had been experiencing panic attack and anxieties for almost 10 years and during that period of time I was admitted to the hospital for 5 times until a doctor whom has had the same problem came with the diagnosis! column2: 45-54 Female  on Treatment for 5 to less than 10 years (Patient) $5$3$5$"Please read this. If your doctor prescribes this medication for Restless Leg Syndrome
column3: don't use it. You can purchase Vitamin B Complex and it will resolve the symptoms naturally. I was on clonazepam for 10 years before I discovered Vitamin B Complex
column4: and I am so addicted to it

column6: and week by week. Otherwise you will experience horrific side effects of withdrawal from the medication. I've also tried Requip for RLS
column7: but had extremely vivid dreams and quit immediately.

column2: and see if it doesn't work for you for RLS.  The clonazepam is extremely addictive and almost impossible to get off of

column2: 19-24 Male  on Treatment for 6 months to less than 1 year (Patient) $5$4$5$Klonopin is the best all-around benzo on the market; however
column3: it is highly addictive.  It works great for many symptoms
column4: especially panic/anxiety; however
column5: your body slowly develops a tolerance for the drug
column6: meaning that you will ultimately have to take more and more for it to demonstrate efficacy
column7: which could push the dosage into dangerous areas.  I believe that around 1.5mg - 2mg has addictive potential
column8: so just be careful.  Also
column9: if you have reached the aforementioned threshold of addictiveness
column10: be VERY careful when trying to get off of Klonopin.  The withdrawal symptoms can be very serious - even deadly (seizures
column11: &c.) - so do not precipitously stop taking the drug.  It is
column13: the best long-acting benzo on the market.

1102$Condition: Panic Disorder$9/18/2007 2:10:37 PM$Reviewer: 19-24 Female  on Treatment for less than 1 month (Patient) $1$1$1$This medication was given to me by my PCP, most likely based on poor judgement. It instantly threw me into a heavy depression, and worsened my condition. I was unnable to move, or get out of bed, or go to work or eat for five days. I felt hopeless, listless, and chronicly sleepy/drowsy. I even took a Provigil one of those days in an attempt to stay awake and fell asleep anyways. I quickly decided to discontinue the use of this medication. It was prescribed to me for anxiety and I highly recommend that if your PCP prescribes this to you for that reason, take it as needed as opposed to the dosing I was instructed to follow which was two 0.5 mg pills daily, in addition to 20 mg Lexapro which I am considering coming off of as well. --Not to mention, none of this helped to ease my anxiety.
